reasoning: The critique targets a sub-argument in §2.3.2 (abundance → altruism via diminishing returns to self-interest). That point is not central to the essay’s main conclusions (the authors already doubt WAM-convergence and only treat abundance as a limited, non-decisive push), so centrality is modest. The critique’s core move—self-interested utility can remain (near-)linear because tech creates new high-ceiling consumption/positional/solipsistic sinks—would weaken that optimism lever, but the essay itself already anticipates much of this (explicitly noting linear self-interested preferences, positional goods, and weak wealth–charity correlations). So it adds limited additional refutation beyond what’s already “priced in,” yielding low strength. The factual/plausibility claims are mostly reasonable though partly speculative (e.g., ‘may never be reached’), and the point is clearly and tightly argued with little fluff.
title: Rising consumption ceilings may prevent self-interest from ever saturating
